'''Alfred Joseph Clements''' (1858 – 6 January 1938) was the Organiser and secretary of the [[Conway Hall Ethical Society|South Place]] Sunday Concerts in London for over 50 years, from 1887–1938.<ref name="Conway Hall">{{cite web|title=Alfred J. Clements|url=http://conwayhall.org.uk/alfred-j-clements|work=Conway Hall|publisher=Conway Hall|accessdate=27 November 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202232912/http://conwayhall.org.uk/alfred-j-clements|archive-date=2013-12-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> These concerts are still running every Sunday today.<ref name="MacKillop1986">{{cite book|author=Ian Duncan MacKillop|title=The British Ethical Societies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mqgsFS_MN9UC&pg=PA106|year=1986|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-26672-7|page=106}}</ref>
In 1901, he was a printer, living with his wife Dora Mary Clements née Varian at 10 Leighton Crescent, Kentish Town, London.<ref name="1901 census">{{cite web|title=1901 England Census|url=http://interactive.ancestry.co.uk/7814/LNDRG13_157_158-0308/2235749|work=1901 census|publisher=Ancestry.co.uk|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref>
When Clements died on 6 January 1938, he was living at 8 Finchley Way, Finchley London. Probate of his will was to his widow, Dora Mary Clements, and his effects totalled £995 10s.<ref>{{cite web|title=England & Wales, National Probate Calendar (Index of Wills and Administrations), 1858-1966|url=http://interactive.ancestry.co.uk/1904/31874_221782-00833/2175138|publisher=Ancestry.co.uk|accessdate=28 November 2013}}</ref>
He is commemorated by a gold inlaid relief plaque at [[Conway Hall]], London. Both Clements and his wife are named in the Book of Remembrance in the Musicians’ Chapel at [[St Sepulchre-without-Newgate]].
A prize was established in his name. In 1947, this prize was won by [[Peter Racine Fricker]] for his Wind Quintet, which was first performed at Conway Hall on 27 February 1947 by the Brain Wind Ensemble, joined by [[George Malcolm (musician)|George Malcolm]], and first broadcast in 1949.<ref name="GambleLynch2011">{{cite book|author1=Stephen Gamble|author2=William C. Lynch|title=Dennis Brain: A Life in Music|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5y2llfXEZJUC&pg=PA40|year=2011|publisher=University of North Texas Press|isbn=978-1-57441-307-6|page=40}}</ref>

'''Algorithmic mechanism design (AMD)''' lies at the intersection of economic [[game theory]] and [[computer science]].
[[Noam Nisan]] and Amir Ronen, from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], first coined "Algorithmic mechanism design" in a research paper published in 1999.<ref name="nisan">{{citation | last1 = Nisan | first1 = Noam | author1-link = Noam Nisan | last2 = Ronen | first2 = Amir | journal = Proceedings of the thirty-first annual ACM symposium on Theory of computing | pages = 129–140 | title = Algorithmic mechanism design | url = http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=301287 | year = 1999}}.</ref><ref name=journal_version>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1006/game.1999.0790|title=Algorithmic Mechanism Design|journal=Games and Economic Behavior|volume=35|pages=166|year=2001|last1=Nisan|first1=Noam|last2=Ronen|first2=Amir}}</ref>
It combines ideas such as utility maximization and mechanism design from [[economics]], rationality and [[Nash equilibrium]] from game theory, with such concepts as [[complexity]] and algorithm design from [[discrete mathematics]] and theoretical [[computer science]]. Examples of topics include networking, [[peering]], online auctions and exchanges, online advertising, and search engine's page ranking.
Algorithmic mechanism design differs from classical economic mechanism design in several respects. It typically employs the analytic tools of [[theoretical computer science]], such as [[worst case analysis]] and [[approximation ratio]]s, in contrast to classical mechanism design in economics which often makes distributional assumptions about the agents. It also considers computational constraints to be of central importance: mechanisms that cannot be efficiently implemented in polynomial time are not considered to be viable solutions to a mechanism design problem. This often, for example, rules out the classic economic mechanism, the [[Vickrey–Clarke–Groves auction]].

{{other people|William Whitlock}} [[File:Billy Whitlock.jpg|thumb|1846 illustration of Whitlock]] '''William M. "Billy" Whitlock''' (1813–1878) was an American [[blackface]] performer. He began his career in entertainment doing blackface [[banjo]] routines in [[circus]]es and [[dime show]]s, and by 1843, he was well known in New York City. He is best known for his role in forming the original [[minstrel show|minstrel]] troupe, the [[Virginia Minstrels]]. ==Early career== Whitlock was born in New York City in 1813. He worked as a [[typesetting|typesetter]] for a religious journal, then went to work for the ''[[New York Herald]]''. Whitlock claimed to have met America's pre-eminent [[banjo]]ist, [[Joel Sweeney]], in 1838 and to have taken some banjo lessons from him. He joined [[P. T. Barnum|P. T. Barnum's]] circus in 1839, where he began his blackface act. By 1840, Whitlock was performing [[circus]]es, museums, and variety shows and had taken the epithet "King of Banjo players, and the Emperor of Extravaganza Singers".18 July 1840. Announcement from Vauxhall Gardens in the ''[[New York Morning Herald]]''. Quoted in Nathan 65. He paired with [[John Diamond (blackface performer)|John Diamond]] for a time, playing [[banjo]] and singing while Diamond danced. Frank Lynch eventually replaced Diamond, though he took "Frank Diamond" as his stage name. Whitlock also partnered with Dan Gardner, who would dress in [[drag (clothing)|drag]] as Whitlock's character "Sambo Squash" made romantic overtures. This playbill, written in the stereotyped [[African American Vernacular English]] that characterized blackface entertainment, describes Whitlock's basic act:
Now dat Massa Whitlock plays so partic'lar combustious, and will sing dat 'fecting song of [[Jenny Get Your Hoe Cake Done|Jinny git your Hoe Cake done]]! and dat first rate ballad of [[Jim Along Josey]]! defying all de niggers in de world to charm de people after dat same manner. Dis very partic'lar nigga will jump, dance, and knock his heels in a way dat Mademoiselle [[Fanny Elssler]] neber did, neber can and neber will do.5 June 1840. Playbill, [[National Theatre, Boston (1836)|National Theatre, Boston]]. Quoted in Nathan 115.
Many years later, Whitlock claimed that his Negro impersonations were based on reality. He would "quietly steal off to some negro hut to hear the darkeys sing and see them dance, taking with him a jug of whiskey to make them all the merrier."13 April 1878. ''[[New York Clipper]]''. Quoted in Emerson 97. ==Virginia Minstrels== In early 1843, Whitlock became one of the founding members of the [[Virginia Minstrels]]. Whitlock's version of the group's founding holds that Whitlock asked [[Musical styles (violin)#Fiddle|fiddler]] [[Dan Emmett]] to practice with him. They did so on a few occasions, but during one such session, [[Frank Brower]] dropped by unannounced and decided to join in on [[bones (instrument)|bones]]. [[Richard Pelham]] soon followed with his [[tambourine]].13 April 1878. ''New York Clipper''. Quoted in Nathan 116–17. The Virginia Minstrels put on a full [[minstrel show]] at the New York [[Bowery Amphitheatre]] on 6 February 1843. Whitlock was the most famous of the foursome,Nathan 115. but soon all four names became well known as they toured New York and Boston. Whitlock's banjo was long-necked and four-stringed, though a fifth was added by 1844. He played the instrument by striking the strings with his fingernail.Nathan 126. Whitlock also did a "Locomotive Lecture", a predecessor to the [[stump speech (minstrelsy)|stump speech]], wherein he feigned a complete lack of knowledge about steam engines and the railroad. Whitlock wrote some music, as well; his "[[Miss Lucy Long]]" became a hit for both the Virginia Minstrels and [[Christy's Minstrels]].Emerson 94. Whitlock and the troupe left for [[Liverpool]], England, on 21 April. They performed several minstrel shows in the British Isles, but they broke up after a performance on 14 July 1843, possibly due to low profits. Whitlock returned to New York City with the group's manager, [[George Wooldridge]]. ==Later career== Back in America, Whitlock returned to his circus blackface act. For a time, he joined [[T. G. Booth]], [[Cool White]], and [[Barney Williams]] as a member of the [[Kentucky Minstrels]]. On 28 July 1845, Whitlock joined Emmett, [[Bryant's Minstrels|Jerry Bryant]], Dan Gardner, and [[Charles "Charlie" White|Charles White]] to form the Operatic Brothers and Sisters. The group put on a week of outdoor performances in [[Hoboken, New Jersey]]. On 23 October, he performed at a [[Benefit concert|benefit]] along with Emmett, Gardner, and other prominent blackface entertainers. His last public blackface performance was at a circus in 1855.Stark 20. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Crawford, Richard (2001). ''America's Musical Life: A History''. W. W. Norton & Company, Inc. * Emerson, Ken (1997). ''Doo-Dah!: Stephen Foster and the Rise of American Popular Culture''. Da Capo Press. * Nathan, Hans (1962). ''Dan Emmett and the Rise of Early Negro Minstrelsy''. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press. * Stark, Seymour (2001). ''Men in Blackface: True Stories of the Minstrel Show''. Xilibris Corporation. * Tosches, Nick (2001). ''Where Dead Voices Gather''. Little, Brown and Company. {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Whitlock, Billy}} [[Category:1813 births]] [[Category:1878 deaths]] [[Category:American banjoists]] [[Category:American male comedians]] [[Category:American male dancers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from New York (state)]] [[Category:19th-century American male actors]] [[Category:American male stage actors]] [[Category:Blackface minstrel performers]] [[Category:Blackface minstrel songwriters]] [[Category:Singers from New York City]] [[Category:American circus performers]] [[Category:19th-century American singers]] [[Category:Comedians from New York City]]

{{Infobox theatre group | name = Burn the Floor | image = | imagesize = | caption = | formed = 1997 | disbanded = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | genre = Ballroom | location = Touring | members = | ArtisticDirector = [[Jason Gilkison]] | notable = [[Peta Roby]] | homepage = {{official website|www.burnthefloor.com/index.html}} }}
'''Burn the Floor''' is a live dance show which has performed around the world, including on [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] in New York City and the [[West End of London|West End]] in London. Since 1997, Burn the Floor has performed in over 130 countries worldwide. The show has also featured several alumni of various international versions of ''[[Dancing with the Stars]]'' and ''[[So You Think You Can Dance]]''.
==Origin== In 1997, [[Elton John]]'s 50th birthday party included a 10-minute performance from a group of [[ballroom dancers]].<!--<ref name="Pacheko Culture Monster, Elton" />--> The birthday party is credited with starting the idea for Burn the Floor.<!--<ref name="Pacheko Culture Monster, Elton" />--> Following John's party, [[Australian]] producer Harley Medcalf spent two years developing the idea.<!--<ref name="Pacheko Culture Monster, Elton" />--> Medcalf brought a showcase of ballroom dance to an Elton John Aids fundraiser two years later.<!--<ref name="Pacheko Culture Monster, Elton" />--> Among the talent Medcalf recruited for his stage show included a choreographer, [[Anthony Van Laast]], and Australian ballroom dancers [[Jason Gilkison]] and Peta Roby.<ref name="Pacheko Culture Monster, Elton">{{cite news|last1=Pacheko|first1=Patrick|title=Culture Monster Post|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2009/08/elton-john-was-just-turning-50-when-burn-the-floor-the-dance-show-which-opens-at-the-longacre-theatre-today-began-its.html|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=2 August 2009|ref=Pacheko Culture Monster Elton}}</ref> By 2000, the show played a two night stint at [[Radio City Music Hall]] in [[New York City, United States of America|New York City]].<ref name="Kisselgoff NY Times 2000 Review">{{cite news|last1=Kisselgoff|first1=Anna|title=DANCE REVIEW; Arthur Murray Must Be Fox-Trotting in His Grave|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/04/07/movies/dance-review-arthur-murray-must-be-fox-trotting-in-his-grave.html|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=7 April 2000|ref=Kisselgoff NY Times 2000 Review}}</ref> The [[New York Times]] said of the production, "Look past the show's brassy facade, with its rock-show production values and attitude (mock ecstasy is the usual facial expression), and there is some complex footwork in what is essentially a suite of deliberately souped-up social dances."<ref name="Kisselgoff NY Times 2000 Review" />
==Early years== In 2001, Jason Gilkison took over the role of [[choreographer]].<ref name="Pacheko Culture Monster, Elton" /> By 2005, an Australian workshop of the show was named "Jason Gilkison's Ballroom."<ref name="Not your grandmother's chacah" /> Through the course of several tours, the production tinkered with what worked.<ref name="Not your grandmother's chacah" /> Growing into a large production requiring seven vehicles to move from city to city, the tour's creative team began to realize that they preferred the show more stripped down and focused on the dancers.<ref name="Not your grandmother's chacah">{{cite news|last1=Pacheko|first1=Patrick|title='Burn the Floor': Not your grandmother's cha-cha|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/aug/02/entertainment/ca-burn-the-floor2|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=2 August 2009|ref=Not your grandmother's chacha}}</ref> According to Gilkison, “The goal was to streamline it, make it more theatrical, reinvent it with the help of the dancers, who had their own ideas of how to make it more contemporary."<ref name="Pacheko Culture Monster, Elton" />
Before the show hit Broadway, it had already been performed in 29 countries.<ref name="Not your grandmother's chacah" />
==Broadway== Burn the Floor performed its first preview show on Broadway on July 25, 2009 at the [[Longacre Theatre]].<ref name="Playbill-Broadway Cast Announced" /> The show opened on August 2, 2009 after eight preview performances.<ref name="Playbill-Broadway Cast Announced">{{cite news|last1=Gans|first1=Andrew|title=Casting Announced for Broadway's Burn the Floor|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/casting-announced-for-broadways-burn-the-floor-161981|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=Playbill.com|date=17 June 2009|ref=Playbill-Broadway Cast Announced}}</ref> [[Maksim Chmerkovskiy]] and [[Karina Smirnoff]], known for appearing on the U.S. television series ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]'', were announced as special guest stars for the first three weeks of performances.<ref name="Playbill-Broadway Cast Announced" /> At the time, Chmerkovskiy and Smirnoff were a couple off stage as well. Gilkison, who had known Chmerkovskiy since 1990, mentioned to Chmerkovskiy before taking the show to Broadway that he was looking for more female dancers.<ref name="Not your grandmother's chacah" /> Chmerkovskiy was a fan of the stage show and suggested he join the cast with Smirnoff.<ref name="Not your grandmother's chacah" />
Following the departure of Chmerkovskiy and Smirnoff, [[Anya Garnis]] and [[Pasha Kovalev]], then known for competing on the U.S. version of ''[[So You Think You Can Dance]]'', took over the roles of featured dancers.<ref name="Anya and Pasha Join">{{cite news|last1=Staff|first1=Broadway.com|title=Star Dancers Anya Garnis and Pasha Kovalev to Join Burn the Floor|url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/133771/star-dancers-anya-garnis-and-pasha-kovalev-to-join-burn-the-floor/|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=Broadway.com|date=4 August 2009|ref=Anya and Pasha Join}}</ref> Ticket sales decreased following the departure of Chmerkovskiy and Smirnoff.<ref name="Playbill Vault Broadway Gross">{{cite web|title=Broadway Grosses : Burn the Floor|url=http://www.playbillvault.com/Grosses/Show/6848/Burn-the-Floor|website=Playbill Vault|accessdate=25 July 2015|ref=Playbill Vault Broadway Gross|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924074204/http://www.playbillvault.com/Grosses/Show/6848/Burn-the-Floor|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=}}</ref> Shortly after their stint in Burn the Floor, Chmerkovskiy and Smirnoff ended their romantic relationship including their engagement.<!--<ref name="Malkin E! Online" />--> Chmerkovskiy agreed to return to the show in November 2009, but he stated he would not perform with Smirnoff.<!--<ref name="Malkin E! Online" />--> Instead, Chmerkovskiy returned partnered with another ''Dancing with the Stars'' pro, [[Kym Johnson]].<ref name="Malkin E! Online">{{cite news|last1=Malkin|first1=Marc|title=Maksim Chmerkovskiy: Kym's In, Karina's Out|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/152340/maksim-chmerkovskiy-kym-s-in-karina-s-out|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=E! Online|date=5 November 2005|ref=Malkin E! Online}}</ref>
The broadway run ended on January 10, 2010.<!--<ref name="Broadway.com BTF Closing" />--> The show had made plans to continue into February, however, those plans were scrapped.<ref name="Broadway.com BTF Closing">{{cite news|last1=Broadway.com|first1=Staff|title=Burn the Floor to Close on January 10; Mary Murphy Joins Closing Cast|url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/140993/burn-the-floor-to-close-on-january-10-mary-murphy-joins-closing-cast/|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=Broadway.com|date=7 December 2009|ref=Broadway.com BTF Closing}}</ref>
===Broadway cast===
====Opening Night==== The opening night cast including the following dancers:<ref name="Playbill Vault Opening Cast">{{cite web|title=Burn the Floor: Opening Night Cast|url=http://www.playbillvault.com/Show/Detail/Cast/6848/Burn-the-Floor-at-Longacre-Theatre|website=Playbill Vault|accessdate=25 July 2015|ref=Playbill Vault Opening Cast|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924125917/http://www.playbillvault.com/Show/Detail/Cast/6848/Burn-the-Floor-at-Longacre-Theatre|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=}}</ref>

====Other cast members==== Throughout the Broadway run, the following dancers joined the cast:<ref name="Playbill Vault Opening Cast" />
* Irina Boubnovskai (arrived August 10, 2009) * [[Artem Chigvintsev]] (September 14, 2009 – October 26, 2009; arrived December 21, 2009) * [[Anya Garnis]] (August 18, 2009 – November 23, 2009) * [[Karen Hauer]] (Arrived December 21, 2009) * [[Derek Hough]] (Arrived January 8, 2009) * [[Pasha Kovalev]] (August 17, 2009 – November 23, 2009) * Mirko Sciolan (Arrived September 14, 2009) * Vaidotas Skimelis (Arrived December 21, 2009) * [[Emma Slater]] (Arrived October 26, 2009) * Karina Stumpfova (Arrived on November 23, 2009) * Gary Wright (November 23, 2009) * [[Mig Ayesa]] (Arrived January 4, 2010)
==West End== In 2010, Burn the Floor performed a limited engagement at the [[Shaftesbury Theatre]] on London's West End. Featured guest stars for the 2010 run included [[Ali Bastian]], a competitor on ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'', and her pro partner from Strictly, [[Brian Fortuna]].<ref name="Bosanquet Fortuna Bastian">{{cite news|last1=Bosanquet|first1=Theo|title=Brian Fortuna, Ali Bastian Set for West End Engagement of Burn the Floor|url=http://www.theatermania.com/london-theater/news/04-2010/brian-fortuna-ali-bastian-set-for-west-end-engagem_26707.html|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=Theater Mania|date=19 April 2010|ref=Bosanquet Fortuna Bastian}}</ref> The show was scheduled to run from July 21-September 5, 2010.<ref name="Bosanquet Fortuna Bastian" />
The show returned to the [[Shaftesbury Theatre]] in 2013, this time with [[Robin Windsor]] and [[Kristina Rihanoff]], pro dancers from ''Strictly Come Dancing'', in the roles of featured guest stars.<ref name="Shenton closing west end">{{cite news|last1=Shenton|first1=Mark|title=Burn the Floor to Shutter at West End's Shaftesbury Theatre June 30|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/burn-the-floor-to-shutter-at-west-ends-shaftesbury-theatre-june-30-192895|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=Playbill.com|date=26 April 2013|ref=Shenton closing west end}}</ref> The 2013 run began on March 6, 2013 and closed on June 30, 2013, although it was originally scheduled to run through September 1.<ref name="Shenton closing west end" />
==World Tours== Following closing on Broadway, the show embarked on a 2010 world tour, which included 30 cities in the [[United States]].<ref name="Broadway.com BTF Closing" />
A new production, ''Burn the Floor – Fire in the Ballroom'', choreographed and directed by [[Peta Roby]], debuted in 2016 at the Regal Theatre in [[Perth, Australia]].<ref name="MacNaughton, Tanya; Fire in Balroom" /><ref name="Media Update, Fire in Ballroom" /> In contrast to previous productions, ''Fire in the Ballroom'' incorporated more rock and roll with the intention of appealing more the male audiences.<!--<ref name="MacNaughton, Tanya; Fire in Balroom" />--> The production's Perth run was scheduled for March 23 through April 3, 2016.<ref name="MacNaughton, Tanya; Fire in Balroom">{{cite news|last1=MacNaughton|first1=Tanya|title=Burn the Floor sizzles even more with Fire in the Ballroom|url=https://www.communitynews.com.au/lifestyle/Burn-the-Floor-sizzles-even-more-with-Fire-in-the-Ballroom/7683144|accessdate=26 March 2016|publisher=Community News|date=29 February 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407080726/https://www.communitynews.com.au/lifestyle/Burn-the-Floor-sizzles-even-more-with-Fire-in-the-Ballroom/7683144|archivedate=7 April 2016|df=}}</ref> In April 2016 the production had scheduled engagements in South Africa, including stops in [[Pretoria]], [[Cape Town]], and [[Durban]].<ref name="Media Update, Fire in Ballroom">{{cite news|title=Burn The Floor returns to South Africa in 2016|url=http://www.mediaupdate.co.za/media/90831/burn-the-floor-returns-to-south-africa-in-2016|accessdate=26 March 2016|publisher=Media Update|date=11 January 2016}}</ref>
''Burn the Floor'' returned to London with the production ''Fire in the Ballroom'' for a limited run, from 18 October to 5 November 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk/news/latest-news/article/item370986/burn-the-floor-returns-with-uk-premiere/|title=Burn The Floor returns with UK premiere|last=Jessop|first=Rachel|date=8 August 2016|website=www.officiallondontheatre.co.uk|publisher=|access-date=23 October 2016}}</ref>
==Alumni== Other notable alumni of Burn the Floor include:
* [[Natalie Lowe]] (joined 2005)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/arts/its-about-sex/2005/09/08/1125772615520.html|title=It's about sex - Arts - Entertainment - smh.com.au|last=|first=|date=|website=www.smh.com.au|publisher=|access-date=1 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://natalielowe.co/natalie-lowe-story/|title=Natalie Lowe - My Story|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=1 October 2016}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * [[Mark Ballas]] (2010–11)<ref name="Gans DWTS joins touring cast">{{cite news|last1=Gans|first1=Andrew|title="Dancing with the Stars" Competitor Mark Ballas to Join Touring Cast of Burn the Floor|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/dancing-with-the-stars-competitor-mark-ballas-to-join-touring-cast-of-burn--173388|accessdate=25 July 2015|date=8 November 2010|ref=Gans DWTS joins touring cast}}</ref> * [[Janette Manrara]] (joined 2010)<ref name="Gans DWTS joins touring cast" /> * [[So You Think You Can Dance Australia (season 3)|Robbie Kemetoni]] (joined 2010)<ref name="Gans DWTS joins touring cast" />
==Cruises== As of 2013, Burn the Floor began giving performances on [[Norwegian Cruise Line|Norwegian Cruise]] ships.<ref name=Saltzman>{{cite news|last1=Saltzman|first1=Duri|title=Legally Blonde, the Musical and Burn the Floor to Headline Next Norwegian Cruise Ship|url=http://www.cruisecritic.com/news/news.cfm?ID=5349|accessdate=25 July 2015|publisher=Cruise Critic|date=9 May 2013|ref=Saltzman}}</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = Chad Valley | logo = | type = [[Subsidiary]] | foundation = Early 19th Century | location = Birmingham (formerly), [[Milton Keynes]], Buckinghamshire | industry = Retail | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = J Sainsbury plc | homepage = [https://www.argos.co.uk/static/ArgosPromo3/includeName/Chad-Valley-shop-toys.htm Chad Valley] | footnotes = }}
[[Image:Chad valley.png|right|thumb|Chad Valley current logo]] '''Chad Valley''' is a long-established brand of [[toy]]s in the United Kingdom owned by [[Sainsbury's]].
== History == [[File:Thinktank Birmingham - object 1984S03753.00015(1).jpg|thumb|A tin-plate Chad Valley toy truck, displaying their royal warrant.]] The company has its roots in a printing business established by Anthony Bunn Johnson in [[Birmingham]] in the early 19th century. Under the management of his son Joseph and grandson Alfred the company moved to the suburb of [[Harborne]], in the valley of a stream called the [[Chad Brook]], giving its name to the [[Chad Valley, Birmingham|Chad Valley]] district, from which the company name is derived.
Chad Valley made a decision to expand their range to [[soft toy]]s before World War I. They mass-produced their new [[Teddy bear]]s in Harborne<ref name=Woolworths>{{cite web|url=http://www.woolworthsmuseum.co.uk/Toys-EarlyCV.html|title=Toys for Toffs - the early history of Chad Valley|accessdate=2015-02-04}}</ref>
In 1938 the company received a [[Royal Warrant of Appointment (United Kingdom)|royal warrant]] as 'Toymakers to H.M. The Queen'.<ref name=Grace /> When Princess Elizabeth acceded to the throne in 1952 the warrant was changed to read 'Toymakers to H.M. Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother'.<ref name=Woolworths />
The company moved away from manufacturing toys in the [[World War II|Second World War]]. Instead they produced goods to help the war effort such as wooden instrument cases, cases for the barrels of anti-aircraft guns, hospital beds and electrical coils and starters.<ref name=Grace>{{cite web|title=Chad Valley Co|url=http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Chad_Valley_Co|website=Grace's Guide|accessdate=12 February 2015}}</ref>
In 1945 the company resumed toy production. [[Tin toy|Tin plate toys]] were produced for the first time although manufacture was outsourced to Metal Box Ltd, a company with the skills and machinery needed to produce printed toys. This new tin plate range was such a success that in 1946 the company moved production in-house. They purchased the Birmingham metalworking company AS Cartwright Ltd to cut and fold metal, Winfield Ltd to produce clockwork mechanisms and Barronia Metals Ltd and True to Type Products Ltd to produce precision engineering equipment.<ref name=ToyPrice>{{cite web|title=The History of Chad Valley|url=http://www.toypriceguide.co.uk/the-history-of-chad-valley/|website=Toy Price Guide|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref>
The radio broadcaster [[Kenneth Horne]] was Chairman and Managing Director of the company from 1956 to 1958.<ref>Johnston, Barry (2006). ''Round Mr Horne: The Life of Kenneth Horne''. Aurum Press. p. 180. {{ISBN|1-84513-123-1}}</ref>
The company was one of the UK's leading toymakers for most of the 20th century, by 1960 it was operating seven factories and employing over 1,000 people. In the 1970s however it closed several factories and cuts were made in staffing and production, 1975 saw only two factories remaining. The company was taken over by [[Palitoy]] in 1978.<ref name=Grace />
The brand name was bought by [[Woolworths Group|Woolworths]] in 1988 and remained in use until that company's closure due to insolvency. [[Home Retail Group]], the parent company of retailers [[Homebase]] and [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]], purchased the brand for £5 million on 20 January 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20090120-709556.html |title=Home Retail Signs Deal To Buys Chad Valley Toy Brand For GBP5M |publisher=Wall Street Journal |date=2009-01-20 |accessdate=2009-01-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121121133/http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20090120-709556.html |archivedate=21 January 2009 }}</ref> The Chad Valley brand is now available exclusively at [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]]. In March 2016 [[Sainsbury's]] bought Home Retail Group and Chad Valley became a brand of Sainsbury's.

[[Vikram Sarabhai]] |leader_title = Director |leader_name = [[Mallika Sarabhai]] |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website ={{URL|http://darpana.com}} |remarks = }} '''Darpana Academy of Performing Arts''' is a school for [[performing art]]s in [[Ahmedabad]], Gujarat, established by [[Mrinalini Sarabhai]] and [[Vikram Sarabhai]] in 1949,{{cite book|last=Epskamp|first=C. P. |author2=Kees Epskamp|title=Theatre for development: an introduction to context, applications and training|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ep3eux75oGkC&pg=PA52&dq=%22Darpana+Academy+of+Performing+Arts%22+-inpublisher:icon&cd=3#v=onepage&q=%22Darpana%20Academy%20of%20Performing%20Arts%22%20-inpublisher%3Aicon&f=false|year=2006|publisher=Zed Books|isbn=1-84277-733-5|page=52}}{{cite web | title = A movement called dance |work=[[Mid Day]]| url = http://www.mid-day.com/articles/a-movement-called-dance/16491194 |first=Suprita | last=Mitter |date=28 August 2015| accessdate = 2016-01-08 }} it has been directed by their daughter [[Mallika Sarabhai]] for the last three decades.{{cite web | title = 10 years later, Mallika Sarabhai back with Sita's Daughters | work=Hindustan Times | url = http://www.hindustantimes.com/art-and-culture/10-years-later-mallika-sarabhai-back-with-sita-s-daughters/story-k7mvgqnzLCtgKRTdibK74O.html |first=Manali | last=Shah|date=28 Aug 2015| accessdate = 2016-01-08 }} The school organises a three-day Interart, the "Vikram Sarabhai International Arts Festival" at Ahmedabad, every year.{{cite news |url=http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/Bid-goodbye-to-2007-on-a-cultural-note/254794/ |title=Bid goodbye to 2007 on a cultural note! |date=27 Dec 2007 |work=Indian Express |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090113152522/http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/Bid-goodbye-to-2007-on-a-cultural-note/254794/ |archivedate=2009-01-13 |df= }} It celebrated its golden jubilee on 28 December 1998, with the announcement of the annual "Mrinalini Sarabhai Award for Classical Excellence", in the field of classical dance.{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/res/web/pIe/ie/daily/19981226/36051964.html|title=Tradition takes over|date=26 December 1998|work=Indian Express|accessdate=20 October 2010}} ==Naming== While ''"darpana"'' is the [[Hindi]] word for "mirror",{{cite web|title=darpana - Meaning in Hindi - darpana in Hindi - Shabdkosh {{!}} शब्दकोश : English Hindi Dictionary and Translation|url=http://www.shabdkosh.com/translate/darpana/darpana-meaning-in-Hindi-English|website=www.shabdkosh.com}} the use here also references the ''"Abhinaya Darpana"'', "The Mirror of Gestures", [[Nandikeshvara]]'s ancient text upon Indian stage-craft and dance.{{cite web|title=Mirror of Gesture (Abhinaya Darpana)|url=https://themathesontrust.org/library/mirror-of-gesture-abhinaya-darpana|website=themathesontrust.org|publisher=[[The Matheson Trust]]|accessdate=15 December 2017}}{{cite web|title=L'Originalité des cultures: son rôle dans la compréhension internationale|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0016/001611/161118fo.pdf|website=unesdoc.unesco.org|publisher=[[UNESCO]] |page=208 |language=French|date=22 July 1953}} ==History== [[File:Vikrambhai and amma .jpg|thumb|Founder of Darpana Academy Dr. Vikram Sarabhai and Mrinalini Sarabhai]] The Darpana Academy of Performing Arts was founded in Ahmedabad, [[Gujarat]], [[India]] by [[Vikram Sarabhai]] and his wife [[Mrinalini Sarabhai]].{{cite web|title=Darpana Academy Official Blog|url=http://darpanaacademy.blogspot.com/}}{{cite web | title = In conversation with danseuse Mallika Sarabhai |work= The Hindu | url = http://www.thehindu.com/features/friday-review/dance/in-conversation-with-danseuse-mallika-sarabhai/article7814196.ece |first=G. S. | last=Paul|date= 29 October 2015|accessdate = 2016-01-08 }}{{cite book|first1=Urmimala | last1=Sarkar Munsi|first2=Stephanie | last2=Burridge|title=Traversing Tradition: Celebrating Dance in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kaepAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA272|date= 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-70379-9|pages=272–}} The work in using arts foe social change began at Darpana in the 1960s. Darpana’s puppeteers started working with the central ministry of rural development in teaching village women the use of smokeless stove. The theatre department then run by [[Kailash Pandya]] created a play called Ma to rally people to the war effort. [[Mrinalini Sarabhai]], in a radical departure from the spiritual core of the classical [[Bharat Natyam]] used the style to talk of the horror of dowry violence. Over the years two departments were established to focus the work of using the arts for change. Darpana for Dvelopment in 1980, today run by actor activist [[Jignesh Patel]], and Darpana Communication in 2001 run by film maker [[Yadavan Chandran]]. In addition, in 2009 CRANTI(Citizens Resource and Action Initiative)was formed to give practical guidance to citizen to use the laws and tools available to them to fight their own battles, and to train people in the use of the Right To Information Act to solve daily problems of access and justice, run by Bharatsinh Jhala. During the last three decades, these departments have worked on over 51 projects all over India, reaching out to over 12.5 million people. The work has been in areas ranging from [[public health]], [[women’s empowerment]], [[gender issues and education to the environment]], [[human rights]], [[communal harmony]], [[good governance]], citizen’s participation in democracy, race, [[gender and disability]]. Through the use of television and film, theatrical and [[street performances]], [[quizzes]] and [[debates]], [[puppets]] and [[board games]]. They have been able to effectively talk about a range of sensitive issues from [[women and violence]], to [[religious intolerance]], the [[Natural environment|environment]], [[human rights]], [[corruption]] and [[justice]]. The academy received [[UNESCO]] sponsorship to offer Artist Residency programs in 1999-2000 and 2005-2007.{{cite web|title=Rapport Du Directeur General Sur Les Activites Du Fonds International Pour La Promotion De La Culture (1998-1999)|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0011/001170/117026f.pdf|publisher=[[UNESCO]]|page=9|language=French|date=27 August 1999}}{{cite web|title=Bursaries for Artists Program UNESCO-Aschberg 2005-2006|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0013/001376/137683m.pdf|publisher=[[UNESCO]]}}{{cite web | title = India - Darpana Academy of Performing Arts|work= UNESCO| url = http://portal.unesco.org/culture/en/ev.php-URL_ID=7211&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html | accessdate = 2016-01-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303201932/http://portal.unesco.org/culture/en/ev.php-URL_ID=7211&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html |archive-date=3 March 2016 }} The academy was also listed by UNESCO an institution active in the "Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage", and thereby invited to attend the subsequent Intergovernmental Committee meetings.{{cite web|last1=Intergovernmental Committee for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage|title=Intangible Cultural Heritage|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0023/002342/234289m.pdf|publisher=[[UNESCO]]|date=5 February 2008}}{{cite web|title=Decision of the Intergovernmental Committee: 2.COM 4 - intangible heritage - Culture Sector|url=https://ich.unesco.org/en/Decisions/2.COM/4|website=ich.unesco.org|publisher=[[UNESCO]]|language=en}} ==Activities== [[File:Darpana Academy .jpg|thumb|dance academy]] The academy offers courses in Indian classical dance [[Bharatanatyam]], Indian Classical Vocal, [[Mridangam]], Violin and Flute, puppetry and martial art [[ Kalaripayattu]]. Its departments range from performance and teaching of the arts, to the use of performance and arts as development communication, through face-to-face impact and software production. The Drama Section, under acting duo [[Kailash Pandya]] and [[Damini Mehta]], is responsible for more than 100 productions of a wide variety. Darpana attracted young writers and staged their first scripts, making them an integral part of production efforts. Some of the names can be mentioned as [[Madhu Rye]], [[Labhshankar Thakar]], [[Shrikant Shah]], [[Subhash Shah]], [[Chinu Modi]], and [[Hasmukh Baradi]]. It also conducted theatre-training courses for over two decades. Its research wing, Janvak, published monographs like Goverdhan Panchal's on [[Bhavai]]. Darpana has also built an experimental thrust auditorium, Natrani, reminiscent of Greek amphitheatres, on the banks of the river Sabarmati. ==List of Kathakali artists and musicians who worked in Darpana since 1949== * Guru [[Vazhenkada Kunchu Nair]], * Kavungal Shankarankutty Panicker, * Guru Kottakkal Gopi Nair, * Kottakkal Appu Nair, * V.P. Ramakrishnan, * Chandramana Govindan Namboodiri, * Mankombu Sivashankara Pillai, * Kalamandalam Govindan Kutty, * Kalamandalam Murali, * Kalamandalam Gopinath, * [[Kavungal Chathunni Panicker]], * Kalamandalam Ravindra Warrior, * Kalamandalam Madhavan, * Kalamandalam Bhaskara Menon, * Thakazhi Kuttan Pillai, * Kalamandalam Unnikrishna Kurup, * Kalamandalam Subrahmanian, * Kalamandalam Sukumaran, * [[Kalamandalam Haridas]], * Kottakkal Narayanan Namboodiri, * Kavungal Gopala Panicker, * Kavungal Krishna Panicker, * Kalamandalam Narayanan, * Kalamandalam Ananda Narayanan, * Kalamandalam Sasi Poduval, * Kalamandalam Balaraman, * Kalamandalam Anandan, * Thichur Vasu Variar, * V.P. Shankara Narayanan, * Kalamandalam Shivaraman Nair, * Kalamandalam Devaki, * Kalamandalam Sitalakshmi, * Painkulam Narayana Chakkyar, * Kalamandalam Hariharan, * Kalamandalam Kalyanikutti Amma, * Kottakkal Sasidharan Nair{{cite web|last=Kottakkal|first=Sasidharan Nair|url=http://kottakkalsasidharan.com/biography.html|work=Kottakkal Sasidharan Nair Biography|accessdate=26 May 2011|title=Biography of Kottakkal Sasidharan Nair}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.darpana.com}} * [http://darpanaacademy.blogspot.com/ Darpana Academy updates] [[Category:Dance schools in India]] [[Category:Organisations based in Ahmedabad]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1949]] [[Category:Education in Ahmedabad]] [[Category:1949 establishments in India]] [[Category:Dance education in India]] [[Category:Drama schools in India]] [[Category:Kalarippayattu]] [[Category:Bharatanatyam]] [[Category:Puppetry in India]] [[Category:Kathakali]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1949]] [[Category:Music schools in India]] [[Category:Performing arts education in India]]

'''Dinosauria Park''' ({{lang-el|Ο Κόσμος των Δεινοσαύρων}}, ''O Kosmos ton Dinosauron'') is a [[dinosaur]] [[Amusement park|park]] located near the town of [[Gournes]] in [[Crete]], [[Greece]], 15 km east of the city of [[Heraklion]]. The park features some fossil replicas and several [[animatronics|animatronic]] dinosaur models. Dinosaur models are displayed along an approximately 500 metre long walk, each accompanied by an information board. The Dinosauria Park started as an idea in 2013 and was first housed in GOURNES ΔΕΚΚ, located in the former American Base. There were hosted 30 different dinosaur species from all periods of the Mesozoic era and other prehistoric animals.
In 2014 the exhibits were transferred to their own space, following intensive efforts to be found in their natural environment and to "revive"! In the large family of dinosaurs new species were added and new sections, such as dinosaurs General Hospital, where young and old fans of dinosaurs can see a dinosaur hatches and begins his life in the park. In the space for creative activities, all become children again, trying to find as many dinosaurs may in tidal area, and playing various "dinosaur games" made in space.
For the visitors there is the opportunity to watch themed films released in 5D and 7D Cinema.
Finally the visitor can enjoy tasty delicacies in Dino Snack Bar where a certified Playground by TUV organisation Hellas and enjoy endless hours of fun and pleasure.
== See also == * [[List of dinosaur parks]] * [[Cretaquarium]]
== External links == * [http://www.dinosauriapark.com/ Dinosauria Park]

{{Infobox company | name = Gaslamp Games, Inc. | logo = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = 27 January 2010 | defunct = 2017 | | location_city = [[Victoria, British Columbia]] | location_country = [[Canada]] | key_people = David Baumgart (Co-Founder)
Dan Jacobsen (Co-Founder)
Nicholas Vining (Co-Founder) | industry = [[Computer and video game industry|Interactive entertainment]] | products = | revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = | homepage = [http://www.gaslampgames.com/ gaslampgames.com] }} '''Gaslamp Games, Inc.''' was an independent [[Video game developer|game developer]] based in [[Victoria, British Columbia]], [[Canada]] which designed [[computer and video game|video games]] for the [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X]], and [[Linux]] operating systems.[http://www.gaslampgames.com Gaslamp Games official site] Their first game, ''[[Dungeons of Dredmor]]'', was released in 2011. Their most recent game, ''Clockwork Empires'', was released in 2016. While the company did not appear to announce it was no longer operating, employees posted on social media that they no longer worked there after the Christmas holiday in 2016. There have also been no social media posts by the company and no further developments to their games after that time. ==Staff== Nicholas Vining, Gaslamp's technical director, has been involved in the game industry since the age of sixteen, when he got his [[Linux gaming]] start working for [[Loki Software]].[http://www.linuxgames.com/archives/15938 Coming Soon: Dungeons of Dredmor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029184631/http://www.linuxgames.com/archives/15938 |date=2010-10-29 }} [[LinuxGames]], October 24th, 2010 (Article by Dustin Reyes) Since then, he has contributed to games developed by [[Piranha Games]], [[3000AD Inc.]], [[Destineer Studios]], and [[TimeGate Studios]]. He has also written for [[Game Developer Magazine]], and is listed as a contributor to the [[OpenGL]] [[Rendering API]] specification. He has also worked with prolific coder [[Ryan C. Gordon]] on various open source and Linux-related projects.[http://linuxgamingnews.org/2010/07/19/classic-roguelike-dungeons-of-dredmor-is-coming-to-gnulinux-soon/ Classic Roguelike : Dungeons of Dredmor Is Coming To GNU/Linux Soon] Linux Gaming News, July 19, 2010 (Article by Maxim Bardin) David Baumgart, Gaslamp's art director, has previously worked as a contractor specialising in 2-D artwork for video games. His list of credited titles includes work for [[Niels Bauer Games]], [[Hexwar Games]], [[Data Spire]], and [[Tactic Studios]]. He also created the logo for the [[Fat binary#FatELF: Universal Binaries for Linux|FatELF]] project.[http://icculus.org/fatelf/ FatELF: Universal Binaries for Linux.] Daniel Jacobsen, Gaslamp's CEO, co-founded the company while working on his undergraduate in physics at the [[University of Victoria]], and their first release, ''[[Dungeons of Dredmor]]'', was his first commercial video game project. In addition to programming and company management, he has also lectured with Nicholas Vining at the University of Victoria on game design, and contributes actively to [[Australian National University|Australian National University's]] [[SkyMapper]] project. ==Releases== Their first project, ''Dungeons of Dredmor'', was released on July 13, 2011.[http://www.linuxgames.com/archives/16446 Dungeons of Dredmor Trailer #4] [[LinuxGames]], January 11, 2011 (Article by Dustin Reyes)[http://www.gamebanshee.com/news/101040-dungeons-of-dredmor-gameplay-trailers-release-date.html Dungeons of Dredmor Gameplay Trailers, Release Date] GameBanshee, January 10, 2011 ''Dungeons of Dredmor'' is a [[roguelike|Rogue-inspired]] [[Dungeon crawl|dungeon crawler]] which embraces [[procedural content generation]].[http://www.lgdb.org/game/dungeons_dredmor Dungeons of Dredmor at the Linux Game Database] Gaslamp's second game, ''Clockwork Empires'', a [[steampunk]] [[city-building game]], was released on [[Steam Early Access]] on August 15, 2014.https://portal.clockworkempires.com/ Version 1.0 of ''Clockwork Empires'' launched on October 26, 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.gaslampgames.com/2016/10/26/clockwork-empires-launched/|title=Clockwork Empires 1.0 launched! {{!}} Gaslamp Games|access-date=2017-06-22}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.gaslampgames.com Gaslamp Games - Official Website] *[https://www.youtube.com/user/GaslampGames Gaslamp Games at YouTube] *[http://www.facebook.com/pages/Gaslamp-Games/106253852740216 Gaslamp Games at Facebook] [[Category:Video game companies of Canada]] [[Category:Video game companies established in 2010]] [[Category:Video game companies disestablished in 2017]] [[Category:2010 establishments in British Columbia]] [[Category:2017 disestablishments in British Columbia]]

'''The Grand Union''' was an [[dance improvisation|improvisational]] [[dance group]] based in [[New York City]] from 1970 to 1976. It grew out of Yvonne Rainer dance company, and her piece ''Continuous Project - Altered Daily''. Rainer's sole authority as choreographer began to slip in early 1970 when the dancers, at her invitation, began to bring in their own materials for the piece.[[Yvonne Rainer|Rainer, Yvonne]]. ''Feelings are Facts'', chapter 14 By late 1970, new members had joined the group and the materials were improvised to a much greater extent. The company, which was still often billed as "Yvonne Rainer and Dancers" in the beginning, chose "The Grand Union" as a name to avoid any obvious associations with dance in order to inoculate themselves against charges that what they were doing was not properly ''dance''. To avoid problems with the [[Grand Union (supermarket)|supermarket chain of the same name]], the group used the legal name "Rio Grand Union".[[Yvonne Rainer|Rainer, Yvonne]]. ''Feelings are Facts'', pg. 335 Dance artists involved with Grand Union included * [[Trisha Brown]] * [[Barbara Dilley]] * [[Douglas Dunn (choreographer)|Douglas Dunn]] * [[David Gordon (choreographer)|David Gordon]] * Nancy Lewis * [[Steve Paxton]] * [[Yvonne Rainer]] Others who performed as guests or rehearsed with the group include: *Becky Arnold *Vicky Ruane *[[Valda Setterfield]] *Lincoln Scott About 6 to 9 dancers would appear for each performance, which generally lasted about 2 hours.[[David Gordon (choreographer)|Gordon, David]]. Remarks made during the "Collaboration: Investigating New Forms" session at the [[Theatre Communications Group]] National Conference in June 1982. Published in "TCG Focus: Combining Forces" in ''Theatre Communications'' (January 1983) In 1982, David Gordon, one of the regular performers, described one concert in Ohio:
[A]n audience of 200 showed up ... [A]fter the first half-hour, there were approximately 150 people left, and after the second half-hour there were 100 people and by the time performance ended there were somewhere between 12 and 20 people left, And those few people who stayed around at the end, asked us where we were going next. "You don't know what this means to us out here," they said. "You don't know what you've done, how you've changed our lives." ... It took me awhile to understand that if 180 people walk out, it isn't the end of the world – if the 20 people left have the best time they've ever had.
== See also == {{Portal|dance}} * [[contact improvisation]] * [[dance improvisation]] * [[Judson Dance Theater]] * [[postmodern dance]] ==References== ;Notes {{reflist}} ;Further reading *Ramsay, Margaret Hupp. ''The Grand Union (1970-1976): An Improvisational Performance Group''. New York: Peter Lang, 1991. {{dance-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Grand Union (Dance Group)}} [[Category:Dance companies in the United States]] [[Category:Performing groups established in 1970]]

The '''history of German journalism''' dates to the 16th century. Germany invented printing, and produced its first newspapers in the 16th century. However, Germany was divided into so many competing states that before [[Unification of Germany|unification]] in 1871, no newspaper played a dominant role.
==Early developments== Merchants in [[early modern Europe]] exchanged financial and commercial news, and some started regular newsletters for their clients. One example of this type of merchant was the 16th-century German financiar, [[Fugger]]. He not only received business news from his correspondents, but also sensationalist and gossip news as well. It is evident in Fugger's correspondence with his network that fiction and fact were both significant parts of early news publications. 16th century Germany also saw subscription-based, handwritten news. Those who subscribed to these publications were generally low-level government officials and also merchants. They could not afford other types of news publications, but had enough money to pay for a subscription, which was still expensive for the time.<ref>Mark Häberlein, ''The Fuggers of Augsburg: Pursuing Wealth and Honor in Renaissance Germany'' (2012)</ref>
In the 16th and 17th century, there appeared numerous printed news sheets summarizing accounts of battles, treaties, kings, epidemics, and special events. In 1609 [[Johann Carolus]] published the first regular newspaper in [[Strasbourg]], comprising brief news bulletins. By the 1620s, numerous major cities had newspapers of 4 to 8 pages appearing at irregular intervals; all were strictly censored. The first daily newspaper appeared in 1660 in Leipzig. [[Prussia]] increasingly became the largest and most dominant of the German states, but it had weak newspapers that were kept under very tight control. Advertising was forbidden, and budgets were very small.<ref>Kenneth E. Olson, ''The History Makers: The Press of Europe from hits Beginnings through 1965'' (1967) pp. 99–134</ref>
The term newspaper became common in the 17th century. However, in Germany, publications that we would today consider to be newspaper publications, were appearing as early as the 16th century. They were discernibly newspapers for the following reasons: they were printed, dated, appeared at regular and frequent publication intervals, and included a variety of news items (unlike single item news mentioned above). The first newspaper according to modern definitions was the ''Strasbourg Relation'', in the early 17th century. German newspapers, like avisis, were organized by the location from which they came, and by date. They differed from avisis in that they employed a distinct and highly illustrated [[title page]], and they applied an overall date to each issue.
The emergence of the new media branch was based on the [[spread of the printing press]] from which the publishing press derives its name. Historian Johannes Weber says, "At the same time, then, as the printing press in the physical, technological sense was invented, 'the press' in the extended sense of the word also entered the historical stage. The phenomenon of publishing was born. The German-language ''Relation aller Fürnemmen und gedenckwürdigen Historien'', printed from 1605 onwards by [[Johann Carolus]] in Strasbourg, was the first newspaper.<ref>Johannes Weber, "Strassburg, 1605: The origins of the newspaper in Europe." ''German History'' 24#3 (2006) pp. 387–412.</ref>
==German Confederation, 1815–1867== {{further information|History of Germany#German Confederation, 1815–1867}} A large number of newspapers and magazines flourished. A typical small city had one or two newspapers; Berlin and Leipzig had dozens. The audience was limited to perhaps five percent of the adult men, chiefly from the aristocratic and middle classes, who followed politics. Liberal papers outnumbered conservative ones by a wide margin. Foreign governments bribed editors to guarantee a favorable image.<ref>Theodore S. Hamerow, ''The Social Foundations of German Unification, 1858-1871: Ideas and Institutions'' (1969) pp. 284–91</ref> Censorship was strict, and the government issued the political news they were supposed to report. After 1871, strict press laws were used by [[Otto von Bismarck|Bismarck]] to shut down the Socialist, and to threaten hostile editors. There were no national newspapers. Editors focused on political commentary, but also included a nonpolitical cultural page, focused on the arts and high culture. Especially popular was the serialized novel, with a new chapter every week. Magazines were politically more influential, and attracted the leading intellectuals as authors.<ref>Kenneth E. Olson, ''The history makers: The press of Europe from its beginnings through 1965'' (LSU Press, 1966) pp. 99–134</ref>
== Weimar Republic == The republic's constitution along with other social forces and the earlier Reich press law of 1874 gave rise to a dispersed, energetic and pluralistic press with a wide range of political opinion after the Great War. The [https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/General-Anzeiger '' Generalanzeiger ''] and the [https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boulevardzeitung '' Boulevardblatt ''] established consumer bases decades earlier. Wire news service and newspaper commercial lending by Ruhr industrial interests sought to influence editorial opinion prior to the Great War and during the republic. <ref>Eksteins, Modris. (1975). The Limits of Reason: the German Democratic Press and the Collapse of Weimar Democracy. London: Oxford University Press. Oxford Historical Monographs series. pp. 78-79. {{ISBN|0-19-821862-1}}. </ref>
==1945–1990== In 1945 the occupying powers took over all newspapers in Germany and purged them of Nazi influence. The American occupation headquarters, the [[Office of Military Government, United States]] (OMGUS) began its own newspaper based in Munich, ''[[Die Neue Zeitung]]''. It was edited by German and Jewish émigrés who fled to the United States before the war. Its mission was to encourage democracy by exposing Germans to how American culture operated. The paper was filled with details on American sports, politics, business, Hollywood, and fashions, as well as international affairs.<ref>Jessica C.E. Gienow-Hecht, "Art is democracy and democracy is art: Culture, propaganda, and the Neue Zeitung in Germany." ''Diplomatic History'' (1999) 23#1 pp. 21–43</ref>

[[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = | genre = | style = | web = }} '''''Hughie''''' is a short two-character play by [[Eugene O’Neill]] set in the lobby of a small hotel on a West Side street in midtown New York during the summer of 1928. The play is essentially a long monologue delivered by a small-time hustler named Erie Smith to the hotel’s new night clerk Charlie Hughes, lamenting how Smith’s luck has gone bad since the death of Hughie, Hughes' predecessor. [[Eugene O’Neill|O’Neill]] wrote ''Hughie'' in 1942, although it did not receive its world premiere until 1958, when it was staged in Sweden at the Royal Dramatic Theatre with [[Bengt Eklund]] as Erie Smith. It was first staged in English at the Theater Royal in [[Bath, England]] in 1963 with [[Burgess Meredith]] as Erie.{{cite web|url=http://www.eoneill.com/library/laconics/2/2b.htm |title=Hughie: Robards' Monte Cristo? |publisher=Eoneill.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}} The play was first presented on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in 1964 starring [[Jason Robards]] as Erie and directed by [[José Quintero]]. Robards received a [[Tony Award]] nomination for his performance, and revived the production in 1975 in [[Berkeley, California]] with [[Jack Dodson]] as Charlie Hughes. Robards and Dodson returned to perform it at the Hyde Park Festival Theatre in 1981 and the Trinity Repertory Theatre in [[Providence, Rhode Island]] in 1991, also televising their performances in 1984 for [[PBS]]. ''Hughie'' has been produced on Broadway three times since the 1964 Robards/Quintero production. In 1975 it was paired in repertory with another short play, ''[[Duet (play)|Duet]]'', this time with [[Ben Gazzara]] as Erie (who also won a Tony Award nomination for the role), and in 1996 by the [[Circle in the Square Theatre]] in a production directed by and starring [[Al Pacino]]. The designers for that production were [[David Gallo]] (sets), Donald Holder (lights), Candice Donnelly (costumes) and John Gromada (sound). The [[Goodman Theater]] in Chicago put on the play in January and February 2010, with [[Brian Dennehy]] in the title role.{{cite web|url=http://www.goodmantheatre.org/season/production.aspx?tess%3D3283 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100228223835/http://www.goodmantheatre.org/season/production.aspx?tess=3283 |archivedate=2010-02-28 |df= }} The production was variously well-reviewed, with emphasis on Dennehy's strong performance.{{cite web|last=Oleksinski |first=Johnny |url=http://leisureblogs.chicagotribune.com/the_theater_loop/2010/01/hughie-and-krapps-last-tape-at-the-goodman-push-pull-and-the-passage-of-time.html |title=Theater Loop - chicagotribune.com |publisher=Leisureblogs.chicagotribune.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-29}}https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/24/theater/24cncdennehy.html{{cite web|url=http://newcitystage.com/2010/01/25/review-hughie-krapp%E2%80%99s-last-tapegoodman-theatre/ |title=Review: Hughie & Krapp’s Last Tape/Goodman Theatre |publisher=Newcity Stage |date=2010-01-25 |accessdate=2014-01-29}} The play was revived in 2013 at the [[Shakespeare Theatre Company]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] with [[Richard Schiff]] as Erie.http://www.shakespearetheatre.org/plays/details.aspx?id=347&source=l It returned for a fourth time to Broadway with [[Forest Whitaker]] as Erie Smith in February 2016. The 2016 revival was directed by [[Michael Grandage]] with Darren Bagert as a lead producer.Paulson, Michael, [http://mobile.nytimes.com/2016/02/07/theater/gambling-on-oneill-forest-whitaker-makes-his-broadway-debut-in-hughie.html "Gambling on O’Neill: Forest Whitaker Makes His Broadway Debut in ‘Hughie’"], New York ''Times'', February 3, 2016. Retrieved 2016-02-03. The production had a shortened run of 55 performances and closed on March 27, 2016.Viagas, Robert, [http://www.playbill.com/article/forest-whitaker-39-s-broadway-hughie-closes-today-com-384890 "Forest Whitaker's Broadway 'Hughie' Closes Today"], ′′Playbill′′, March 27, 2016. Retrieved 2017-12-03. ''Hughie'' has been televised at least four times in addition to the 1984 Robards/Dodson version: in 1959 (for Swedish television), 1960 (Norwegian television), 1963 (Dutch television) and 1983 (French television).[https://www.imdb.com/find?s=all&q=Hughie ''Hughie'' on the Internet Movie Database] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ibdb.com/Show/View/4564 ''Hughie'' on the Internet Broadway database] {{Eugene O'Neill}} [[Category:1942 plays]] [[Category:Plays by Eugene O'Neill]] [[Category:Plays set in the 1920s]] [[Category:Plays set in New York City]] [[Category:Two-handers]]

{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} Sir '''Ian Bruce Hope Hunter''' (2 April 1919{{spaced ndash}}5 September 2003) was a British [[impresario]] of classical music. Known as 'Mr. Festival' to many in the arts world, Hunter was one of the most important figures in a post-[[World War II]] cultural renaissance in the United Kingdom. From the mid-1950s, following the death of [[Harold Holt (impresario)|Harold Holt]], he headed the [[music management]] agency Harold Holt Ltd, which joined with Lies Askonas Ltd in the late 1990s to form Askonas Holt. ==Biography== Born in [[Hadley Wood]], [[Middlesex]], Hunter began his career in 1947, as assistant to artistic director [[Rudolf Bing]] at the very first [[Edinburgh Festival]]. He succeeded Bing as the festival's director in 1950, remaining in the position through 1955. He served as the director of numerous other festivals, including the Bath Festival from 1948 to 1968, the City of London Festival from 1962 to 1980, the Brighton Festival from 1967 to 1983, and festivals in Windsor and Hong Kong. "Festivals," he once said, "are like sudden [[fireworks]] in a dark sky."
"Characteristic of Hunter's capacity for thinking big was the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] Arts Festival of 1965. In preparing it he visited 23 countries, and it was held simultaneously, over two weeks, in London, Glasgow, [[Cardiff]] and [[Liverpool]]. Dance was strongly featured: [[Caribbean]], [[African dance|African]] and [[Dance in India|Indian]] groups rubbed friendly shoulders with classical companies from Australia and Canada. [[Jazz]] jostled with the classics. [[Yehudi Menuhin|Menuhin]] shared a platform with [[Ravi Shankar]]. Balloons were released and fireworks rocketed."
Hunter was also a talent manager, celebrated as chairman of Harold Holt Ltd. (now Askonas Holt Ltd.) from 1953 to 1988. He died in [[Balcombe, West Sussex]] at the age of 84. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2003/09/09/db0902.xml&sSheet=/portal/2003/09/09/ixportal.html |title= Sir Ian Hunter |author= Obituary |work= [[The Daily Telegraph]] |date= 9 September 2003 |quote= Mr Festival, as Hunter was known to many in [[the arts]] world, was one of the shrewdest and most energetic managers and promoters of the arts in this country. [[Daniel Barenboim|Barenboim]], [[Yehudi Menuhin|Menuhin]], [[Jacqueline du Pré]], [[Pinchas Zukerman|Zuckerman]], [[Itzhak Perlman|Perlman]], [[Murray Perahia|Perahia]], [[Simon Rattle|Rattle]] and [[John Eliot Gardiner|Gardiner]] were among the many musicians who benefited from his friendship and support. }} {{cite web |url= http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/index.cfm?id=997892003 |title= Tributes for man dubbed 'Mr Festival' |author= Ruth Armstrong |work= [[Edinburgh Evening News]] |date= 10 September 2003 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{cite web |url= http://www.scena.org/columns/lebrecht/030917-NL-IMG.html |title= Changing Hands |author= [[Norman Lebrecht]] |work= The Lebrecht Weekly, La Scena Musicale, Canada's Free Classical Music Magazine |date= 17 September 2003 |quote= Time was when most matters of musical significance in Britain passed through the hands of Ian Hunter, a shrewd backstager of [[Scottish people|Scots descent]] who founded multiple festivals – [[City of London]], [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], [[Brighton]], [[Windsor, Berkshire|Windsor]], [[Malvern, Worcestershire|Malvern]], Hong Kong and beyond. For 35 years Hunter was head of Harold Holt Ltd, the most prestigious classical agency in Britain. }} {{cite web |url= http://www.wipo.int/amc/en/domains/decisions/html/2000/d2000-0392.html |title= Administrative Panel Decision |work= [[World Intellectual Property Organization|WIPO]] Arbitration and Mediation Center |date= 3 July 2000 }} {{cite web|url=http://www.askonasholt.co.uk/green/green/home.nsf/about |title=The History of Askonas Holt |work=Askonas Holt website |quote=Harold Holt Ltd was founded in 1876 by [[Alfred Schulz-Curtius|Alfred Schultz Curtius]], who was the first impresario to bring [[Richard Wagner]]'s music to the London public. The company became renowned for its presentations in the latter part of the 19th century and into the 20th century, with South African-born Harold Holt taking over in the 1930s… The arrival of Sir Ian Hunter in 1956 from the [[Edinburgh International Festival|Edinburgh Festival]] brought a new dimension of artists and festival direction. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116171529/http://www.askonasholt.co.uk/Green/Green/Home.nsf/about |archivedate=16 November 2007 |df= }} {{cite web |url= http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20030915/ai_n12704210 |title= Obituary: Sir Ian Hunter |author= Tim Bullamore |work= [[The Independent]] |date= 15 September 2003 }} {{cite web |url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article1157162.ece?token=null&offset=0 |title= Sir Ian Hunter: Artistic Director of the Edinburgh Festival in the 1950s who established it as the greatest in the world |work= [[The Times]] |date= 10 September 2003 |quote= To describe Ian Hunter as the most successful impresario of his generation is to undervalue a large part of his achievement. He was surely unique in migrating from the promotional world of the performing arts – whether commercial or subsidised – to the sphere of disinterested charitable activity. |location=London}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hunter, Ian}} [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:2003 deaths]] [[Category:Impresarios]] [[Category:Arts managers]] [[Category:Talent managers]] [[Category:Music promoters]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:Knights Bachelor]] [[Category:People from Hadley Wood]] {{UK-music-bio-stub}}
